abstract.p: Frank Robinson letter questions value of social norming campaigns to cut collegiate drinking (Oct 3 article)

block.p: Social norming campaigns to cut collegiate drinking miss the mark (front page, Oct. 3). They challenge students' perceptions of other students' use of alcohol, not their own distorted views of alcohol. These programs perpetuate peer influence by asking students to consider -- and adopt -- their peers' use of alcohol. Groupthink is reinforced, not challenged. An education for critical thinking, not campaigns for conformity, would seem a better strategy.

Social norming campaigns to cut collegiate drinking miss the mark (front page, Oct. 3). They challenge students' perceptions of other students' use of alcohol, not their own distorted views of alcohol. These programs perpetuate peer influence by asking students to consider -- and adopt -- their peers' use of alcohol. Groupthink is reinforced, not challenged. An education for critical thinking, not campaigns for conformity, would seem a better strategy.
In addition, social norming campaigns are based on the questionable premise that students incorrectly perceive their peers' use, but accurately perceive and report their own use.
The writer is a residential life administrator at Ohio University.
